newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico soybean harvest seen below 50,000 T in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Mexico soybean harvest seen below 50,000 T in 1997.

text.p: Mexico's soybean harvest is seen weak again this year due to a continued pest problem in one growing zone and a lack of finance, the local office of American Soybean Association (ASA) said Thursday.

"Given the white fly plague in the northeast and the reticence of banks to finance soybean planting, we do not expect a soybean harvest of over 50,000 tonnes this calendar year," ASA said in an update.
Estimates put the 1996 crop at around 50,000 tonnes, down from the 135,000 tonne output of 1995, although a far cry from the near 1.0 million tonne outputs recorded in the late 1980s.

"Therefore, the current velocity of imports of soybeans can only be expected to continue over the remainder of the marketing year. It is possible that we may have another record volume of soybean imports," ASA said.
Mexico imported a record 2.6 million tonnes of soybeans in the October 1995-1996 marketing year and a similar amount over the 1996 calendar year.
Soybean souces estimate imports this marketing and calendar year will be between 2.7 million and 3.0 million tonnes.
